nodes.title: Build Phish Stats Visualizer
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Build a Phish stats visualizer using D3.js. The goal is to go beyond what phish.net and iHoz already offer by creating more creative, insightful visualizations of a user's Phish show attendance. Key areas: yearly tour views, friend comparisons (who saw what, overlap), bustout tracking, repeated songs across different performances, song duration trends (e.g. longest Tweezers), and jam chart commentary integration. Data comes from phish.net API first, with Playwright scraping as fallback for data not available via API. Starting with user \"someguyorwhatever\" as the test case. Using D3.js for all visualizations."}

nodes.title: Use D3.js for visualization
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Chose D3.js for visualization because it gives us full control over creative graph types - we want to go beyond standard bar/line charts that phish.net and iHoz already offer. D3 lets us build things like force-directed graphs for song relationships, radial layouts for tour timelines, heatmaps for song duration variance, and interactive comparison views between friends' attendance. The tradeoff is D3 has a steeper learning curve than charting libraries like Chart.js, but the creative ceiling is much higher which is exactly what this project needs."}

nodes.title: Song duration/length is a key metric
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Song duration is probably more interesting than just song counts. Tracking how long a song was played at each show opens up analysis like: which shows had the longest jams, how does a song's average length change over years/eras, comparing your attended versions of a song to the all-time longest/shortest versions, and finding outlier performances. This is data that phish.net may not surface well but phish.in (which has audio recordings with track durations) likely has."}

nodes.title: Researching phish.net API capabilities
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"Systematically investigated both phish.net API v5 and phish.in API v2 to understand what data is available programmatically vs what requires scraping. Approach: read API docs, tested endpoints, documented response schemas, identified coverage gaps. This research produced 13 observation nodes (17-29) mapping the complete data landscape. Key finding: phish.net handles structured show/setlist/attendance data while phish.in provides the critical song duration/audio data that phish.net lacks. Some narrative content (jam chart commentary, song history essays) likely requires Playwright scraping."}

nodes.title: Must log ALL decisions in deciduous even during planning
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":100,"prompt":"Process observation: the deciduous decision graph must be maintained even during planning/research phases, not just during implementation. Every decision point, observation, and action during API research and feature planning needs to be logged in real-time. This is important because the planning phase produces the most critical architectural decisions that downstream implementation depends on - if these aren't captured, we lose the reasoning behind the project's foundation."}

nodes.title: Key visualization features to build
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Need to decide which visualization features to build first and which give the most \"wow\" factor beyond what phish.net/iHoz already show. The goal is creative, unique insights - not just repackaging the same stats in a different chart. Each feature should reveal something you can't easily see on existing sites. Prioritizing features that combine multiple data sources (API + scraped commentary) for richer context."}

nodes.title: Yearly tour summary view
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Yearly tour summary view: A \"year in review\" style visualization for a user's Phish attendance. Shows total shows attended per year, venues visited, unique songs heard, total music duration experienced, geographic spread of shows, and highlight moments (bustouts, notable jams). Uses phish.net attendance API for show list, phish.in for duration data, and D3.js for a rich interactive timeline/dashboard layout. This is the anchor feature - most users want to see their year summarized. Data source: computeYearStats function in functional core aggregates the raw data."}

nodes.title: Friend comparison mode
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Friend comparison mode: Side-by-side visualization comparing two or more users' Phish attendance. Shows overlap (shows both attended), unique shows per person, shared songs heard, who saw the longer/better version of a song, venue overlap, and \"jealousy stats\" (notable shows one friend saw but the other missed). Requires phish.net attendance API queried for multiple usernames. D3.js could use a Venn diagram, parallel coordinates, or linked timeline approach. The social/competitive element makes this highly shareable and engaging."}

nodes.title: Bustout tracker
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Bustout tracker: Identify songs that hadn't been played in a long time and then appeared at a show the user attended. This is exciting because bustouts are special moments in Phish fandom. Need gap data (how many shows since last played) combined with user attendance data. Could visualize as a timeline showing the \"drought\" before the bustout, how rare it was, and whether the user was there for it."}

nodes.title: Song repeat analysis across shows
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Song repeat analysis: Visualize which songs a user has heard multiple times across different shows, and how those performances varied. For each repeated song, show the dates/venues where it was played, duration of each performance, any that were jam chart entries, and how the user's version compares to the all-time statistics. Could use a small multiples approach with D3 showing each song as a row with dots for each performance. Helps answer \"how many Tweezers have I seen and were any of them special?\" Data sources: phish.net setlists + phish.in track durations."}

nodes.title: Song duration heatmaps and trends
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Song duration heatmaps and trends: Visualize how long specific songs are played across all performances using heatmaps, box plots, or ridge plots. Show the distribution of durations for a given song (e.g., all Tweezers ever played), highlight outliers (unusually long or short versions), and overlay which versions the user attended. Could also show era-based trends (1.0 vs 2.0 vs 3.0 vs 4.0 average duration). Primary data source is phish.in API v2 which has track-level duration in milliseconds. D3.js heatmap or violin plot would be ideal."}

nodes.title: Jam chart commentary integration
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"Jam chart commentary integration: Surface the narrative context from phish.net's jam chart entries alongside the quantitative data. Jam charts identify performances that are particularly notable for extended improvisation, and each entry typically has fan-written commentary explaining WHY a jam is special (e.g., \"Type II bliss jam that segues into a dark minor key exploration\"). Integrating this commentary with duration data and user attendance creates a rich view: \"You were at the 3rd longest Tweezer ever played, here's why fans consider it legendary.\" May require Playwright scraping since phish.net API's jamcharts endpoint may only return metadata, not full commentary text."}

nodes.title: Data acquisition strategy - API vs scraping
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":75,"prompt":"The phish.net API v5 gives us structured data for shows, setlists, attendance, jam charts, reviews, songs, venues, and users. But some rich contextual data like detailed jam chart commentary, song history narratives, and gap analysis may not be fully available via API. Need to determine: what can we get from API alone, what requires scraping, and whether phish.in (separate site with audio/duration data) fills in the gaps. Playwright scraping is the fallback for anything the API can't provide."}

nodes.title: Phish.net API for structured data
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Option: Use phish.net API v5 exclusively for all data. Pros: structured JSON responses, official API with documented endpoints, covers shows/setlists/attendance/songs/venues/reviews/jamcharts. Cons: no song duration data (phish.net tracks setlist order but not performance length), rate limits exist but are unquantified, API key required, and some rich content like detailed jam chart commentary may not be fully exposed via API. This option alone is insufficient because it lacks the duration data that powers our most interesting visualizations."}

nodes.title: Playwright scraper for commentary/jam charts
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":70,"prompt":"Option: Use Playwright browser automation to scrape phish.net pages directly for data not available via API. Targets: jam chart commentary text (narrative descriptions of why a jam is notable), song history essays, detailed gap charts, and any other rich content embedded in HTML pages. Pros: access to ALL content visible on the site. Cons: fragile (breaks when site layout changes), slower than API calls, potentially violates ToS, requires maintaining CSS selectors, and adds Playwright as a heavy dependency. Best used as a targeted supplement rather than primary data source."}

nodes.title: Hybrid: API for core data + scraping for enrichment
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Option: Hybrid approach combining multiple data sources. phish.net API v5 for core structured data (shows, setlists, attendance, songs, venues), phish.in API v2 for audio-derived data (song durations, track metadata, era aggregates), and Playwright scraping only for narrative content not available via either API (jam chart commentary text, song history essays). This is the recommended approach because it maximizes data coverage while minimizing scraping fragility. Each source fills gaps the others have: phish.net = who/what/where, phish.in = how long, scraping = why it matters."}

nodes.title: phish.net API v5 has 10 endpoints: artists, attendance, jamcharts, reviews, setlists, shows, songdata, songs, users, venues
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Confirmed phish.net API v5 at https://api.phish.net/v5 has 10 core endpoints. Authentication is via API key (GET or POST param, obtainable at phish.net/api/keys/). Supports JSON/XML/HTML response formats. Can query by column/value patterns like /v5/shows/showdate/YYYY-mm-dd.json. Has sorting (order_by, direction) and limit params. Local caching is explicitly permitted but warns against excessive requests. Key endpoints for our use: attendance (user show history), setlists (songs per show), jamcharts (notable versions), shows (show metadata), songdata (extended song info with lyrics/history)."}

nodes.title: phish.in is a separate API with audio data - may have song durations
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":70,"prompt":"Early discovery during API research that phish.in (a separate site from phish.net focused on live audio recordings) has its own API. This was significant because it suggested song duration data might be available programmatically rather than requiring audio file analysis. This observation was the precursor to the deeper investigation documented in nodes 21-26 which confirmed phish.in API v2 as the primary source for duration data. The key insight: phish.net and phish.in are complementary data sources maintained by overlapping but distinct communities."}

nodes.title: Deciduous nodes need detailed how/why context, not just titles - makes recovery and reasoning much more useful
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":100,"prompt":"Meta-process observation: during the initial planning/research phase, many deciduous nodes were created with only titles and no descriptive context. This makes the decision graph less useful for context recovery because titles alone don't capture the reasoning, tradeoffs, or details behind a decision. Going forward, every node should have a prompt/description that explains HOW something was done (for actions), WHY it matters (for observations), WHAT the tradeoffs were (for decisions), and WHAT the result was (for outcomes). This observation itself prompted the audit workflow to backfill descriptions on sparse nodes."}

nodes.title: Bootstrap React + Vite project with functional core / imperative shell architecture
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"have a subagent go in and bootstrap the react project, it should use vite and react and make sure we built with the idea of a functional core and an imperative shell, we will utilize vitest to have a test driven development workflow that will emphasize teh idea of a pure functional core with an imperative shell that pushes complexity to the edges so that we can have very complete unit test coverage at the base as well as use these unit tests to compose the higher order functionalities that will come along"}

nodes.title: phish.in API v2 confirmed as the source for song DURATION data - tracks have duration field in milliseconds, shows have total duration, can sort shows by duration. This is THE key source for song length analysis that phish.net API doesn't provide.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":95}

nodes.title: phish.in show endpoint returns rich track-level data: each track has id, position, duration, slug, title, set_name, mp3_url, waveform_image_url, tags (with notes/timing), and nested songs with performance history. This means we can correlate phish.in tracks to phish.net songs for combined analysis.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90}

nodes.title: phish.in has a years endpoint that returns era designations, shows_count, shows_with_audio_count, shows_duration, venues_count per year - perfect for yearly overview visualizations without having to compute aggregates ourselves.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90}

nodes.title: phish.in has search endpoint that searches across shows, tracks, songs, venues, tags - useful for finding specific performances. Also has proximity-based show filtering (lat/lng/distance) which could power a map visualization.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85}

nodes.title: phish.in shows endpoint supports filtering by: year, year_range, venue_slug, tag_slug, start/end date, us_state, liked_by_user. Sort by: date, likes_count, duration, updated_at. This gives us powerful query capabilities without needing to download everything.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90}

nodes.title: phish.in songs endpoint has 978 total songs. Each song has: slug, title, alias, original (bool), artist, tracks_count, tracks_with_audio_count. Can filter by first_char, sort by title/tracks_count/updated_at.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85}

nodes.title: phish.net API requires API key (GET/POST param) obtainable at phish.net/api/keys/. API docs recommend: never request user passwords, prefer POST over GET, keep authkey hidden from end users. Rate limits exist but aren't explicitly quantified - just warns apps demanding too much data will be disabled.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90}

nodes.title: The phish.net attendance endpoint is what we need for user-specific show history - querying by username to get which shows a user attended. This is the core data for 'your year in review' and friend comparisons. Combined with phish.in track durations, we can calculate what music each user experienced.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90}

nodes.title: Data NOT available via either API that likely needs scraping: detailed jam chart commentary/notes (narrative descriptions of why a jam is notable), song history essays, user-submitted reviews with full text, and gap chart rankings. phish.net API has jamcharts endpoint but unclear if it includes the full commentary text vs just metadata.
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":75}

nodes.title: Writing comprehensive PLAN.md based on API research findings - documenting data sources (phish.net API v5 + phish.in API v2 + Playwright scraping), visualization features (yearly review, friend comparisons, bustouts, song durations, jam charts), tech stack (D3.js), and phased implementation approach
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Synthesized all API research findings (nodes 17-29) into a comprehensive PLAN.md document. The plan documents: (1) data sources - phish.net API v5 for structured show/setlist/attendance data, phish.in API v2 for song duration/audio metadata, Playwright scraping for narrative content; (2) visualization features prioritized by uniqueness and feasibility - yearly review, friend comparisons, bustout tracker, song duration analysis, jam chart integration; (3) tech stack - D3.js for visualization, React+Vite+TypeScript for app shell; (4) phased implementation approach starting with data layer, then core analytics functions, then visualizations."}

nodes.title: Scaffolding Vite React-TS project with functional core / imperative shell architecture
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Initial scaffolding of the Vite + React + TypeScript project structure. Created the directory layout following functional core / imperative shell architecture: src/core/ for pure functions (transforms, aggregations, computations with no side effects), src/shell/ for imperative code (API clients, DOM manipulation, state management), and src/components/ for React UI. Installed dependencies: react, react-dom, d3, vitest, @testing-library/react. Configured Vite, TypeScript with strict mode, and path aliases (@core/, @shell/, @components/)."}

nodes.title: Scaffolding Vite React-TS project with TDD workflow
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Refined the project scaffold specifically for TDD workflow. Configured Vitest with jsdom environment for React component testing, set up test file conventions (*.test.ts alongside source files in src/core/), created test utilities and shared fixtures. The functional core / imperative shell architecture is specifically designed to make TDD natural: pure functions in src/core/ are trivially testable (input -> output, no mocks needed), while imperative shell code in src/shell/ handles side effects and is tested separately with integration tests."}

nodes.title: Creating test-setup.ts and updating tsconfig for path aliases
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Created test-setup.ts to configure the Vitest testing environment: jsdom setup for DOM testing, global test utilities, and any shared before/after hooks. Updated tsconfig.json to add path aliases (@core/* -> src/core/*, @shell/* -> src/shell/*) so that imports in both source and test files use clean paths. This was a prerequisite for the TDD workflow - tests need to import core functions via the same aliases used in production code."}

nodes.title: Scaffold complete: Vite+React+TS+Vitest+D3 with functional core/imperative shell dirs
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Scaffold is fully functional: Vite 7 dev server with React 19 + TypeScript strict mode, Vitest test runner with jsdom for React testing, D3.js v7 for future visualizations, path aliases (@core/*, @shell/*) for clean imports, and the functional core/imperative shell directory structure. The functional core (src/core/) contains pure types and transforms - no React, no side effects, just data in -> data out. The imperative shell (src/shell/) will contain API calls, React hooks, and components that orchestrate the pure core."}

nodes.title: Scaffold committed
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","commit":"ebbc86d","confidence":95,"prompt":"Git commit of the complete project scaffold (commit ebbc86d). Includes: package.json with all dependencies, vite.config.ts, tsconfig.json with path aliases, vitest config, test-setup.ts, directory structure (src/core/, src/shell/, src/components/), and initial placeholder files. This commit establishes the foundation that all subsequent TDD cycles build upon."}

nodes.title: Writing FAILING test for formatDuration - converts ms to human-readable string
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"TDD Red Phase: Wrote 5 failing tests for formatDuration, the first pure function in the functional core. formatDuration converts milliseconds (from phish.in track duration data) to human-readable strings like \"12m 34s\" or \"1h 23m 45s\". Test cases cover: zero duration, seconds only, minutes and seconds, hours/minutes/seconds, and edge cases. This is the foundation utility used by all duration-based visualizations (song length heatmaps, yearly stats, etc.)."}

nodes.title: formatDuration tests failing (5/5) - red phase committed
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","commit":"66637bc","confidence":95,"prompt":"TDD Red Phase committed (66637bc): All 5 formatDuration tests confirmed failing as expected. The test file exists but the implementation file either doesn't exist or has a stub. This follows strict TDD discipline - tests are committed in the failing state before any implementation, proving the tests actually test something meaningful and aren't accidentally passing."}

nodes.title: Implementing formatDuration to make tests pass (green phase)
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"TDD Green Phase: Implemented formatDuration as a pure function in src/core/. Takes milliseconds as input, returns formatted string. Implementation approach: extract hours/minutes/seconds via integer division and modulo, conditionally include hours component, always show minutes and seconds. No side effects, no dependencies - a pure transformation function that exemplifies the functional core pattern."}

nodes.title: formatDuration tests passing (5/5) - green phase committed
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","commit":"20e213e","confidence":95,"prompt":"TDD Green Phase committed (20e213e): All 5 formatDuration tests now passing. Implementation is minimal - just enough code to make the tests pass, following TDD's \"simplest thing that works\" principle. Function is exported from src/core/ and ready to be composed into higher-level functions like computeYearStats."}

nodes.title: Writing FAILING test for groupShowsByYear - groups Show[] into year-keyed map
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"TDD Red Phase: groupShowsByYear takes a Show[] and returns Map<number, Show[]> keyed by year. This is the foundational grouping function for the yearly tour summary view (option #7). It parses the YYYY-MM-DD date string to extract year. Tests cover: multi-year grouping, empty input, correct year extraction from date strings. This enables the 'Your Year in Phish' view."}

nodes.title: groupShowsByYear tests failing (3/3) - red phase committed

nodes.title: Implementing groupShowsByYear to make tests pass (green phase)
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"TDD Green Phase: Implemented groupShowsByYear as a pure function. Takes Show[] and returns Map<number, Show[]>. Implementation: iterates shows, extracts year from show date, groups into Map buckets. No mutations of input data - creates new arrays for each year group. This is a classic functional transformation that composes with computeYearStats downstream."}

nodes.title: groupShowsByYear tests passing (8/8) - green phase committed

Function correctly groups shows by year, handles empty input, single shows, and multi-year spans. Ready for composition with computeYearStats."}

nodes.title: Writing FAILING test for computeYearStats - aggregates show+track data into YearStats

It counts shows, unique venues, unique songs, total music duration (in ms from phish.in), and states visited (deduplicated). This is the core computation behind the yearly tour summary visualization. Tests verify all aggregations including edge cases like empty tracks and duplicate states."}

nodes.title: Vite React-TS project scaffolded with functional core/imperative shell architecture - 43 tests passing

The TDD workflow is proven: formatDuration, groupShowsByYear, and computeYearStats all implemented via red-green cycles. The functional core / imperative shell architecture is working as designed - all core functions are pure, testable without mocks, and compose together. This validates the architectural decision (node 20) and proves the approach scales."}

nodes.title: Writing FAILING test for findBustouts - finds songs with gaps exceeding a threshold

Directly powers the Bustout Tracker visualization (option #9)."}

nodes.title: Implementing findBustouts to make tests pass (green phase)
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"TDD Green Phase: Implemented findBustouts as a pure function. nodes.title: Build lyrics SQLite DB with full-text search and AI-powered thematic query
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"lets make a subagent to do a little research project, we want to have some parallel work going that will

2) allow us to have full text search over this
3) allow us to shell out to you (claude -p) and then look through this to query about things with fuerther and find things like songs with a specific theme vs exact words

and then we can have a simple interface over all this to allow us to find songs or lyrical sections that match an idea for something like a sticker etc"}

nodes.title: Writing FAILING test for computeShowDurationRank - ranks shows by total track duration
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"TDD Red Phase: Wrote failing tests for computeShowDurationRank, which ranks a collection of shows by their total track duration. Takes Show[] with nested Track[] (each having duration in ms from phish.in data) and returns shows sorted by total duration with rank numbers. This powers the \"longest shows\" aspect of duration visualization (option node 11) and helps answer \"was this the longest show I attended?\" Directly relates to song duration heatmaps feature."}

nodes.title: Research and plan Phish lyrics SQLite database architecture
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Research and plan the architecture for a Phish lyrics SQLite database for the phstats project at /Users/robertgrayson/code/phstats.

The goal is:
1. Get all original Phish songs (no covers) and their lyrics, store in a SQLite DB
2. Enable full-text search (FTS5) over lyrics
3. Support AI-powered thematic search by shelling out to `claude -p` to find songs matching themes/ideas (not just exact words)
4. Simple CLI/interface to find songs or lyrical sections matching an idea (e.g., for sticker designs)

Research needed:
1. Where can we get Phish lyrics? Check phish.net API (does it have lyrics?), or do we need to scrape? What other sources exist?
2. How many original Phish songs are there approximately? (phish.in said ~978 total, but some are covers)
3. What's the best SQLite FTS5 schema for lyrics search?
4. How should we structure the `claude -p` integration for thematic queries?

DO NOT write any code. Just research and return a detailed plan including:
- Data source(s) for lyrics and how to obtain them
- SQLite schema design with FTS5
- How the thematic search pipeline would work (FTS5 for keyword search -> claude -p for semantic/thematic refinement)
- File structure recommendation within the existing project

Return your findings as a structured report."}

nodes.title: phish.net API v5 songdata endpoint includes lyrics field
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Key finding during lyrics database research: the phish.net API v5 songdata endpoint already includes a lyrics field, meaning we can obtain song lyrics programmatically without scraping. This is significant because it means the lyrics SQLite database (goal node 53) can be populated entirely via API calls rather than requiring Playwright scraping of lyrics pages. The songdata endpoint returns: songid, song, slug, abbr, artist, debut, last_played, times_played, gap, and critically the lyrics field with full song text. This applies to original Phish compositions; covers may have limited/no lyrics data."}

nodes.title: showDurationRank tests failing (2/2) - red committed
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","commit":"8da59ed","confidence":95,"prompt":"TDD Red Phase committed (8da59ed): 2 computeShowDurationRank tests confirmed failing. Tests verify that shows are correctly ranked by total track duration, handling ties and shows with no track data."}

nodes.title: Implementing computeShowDurationRank to make tests pass (green phase)
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"TDD Green Phase: Implemented computeShowDurationRank as a pure function. Sums track durations per show, sorts descending, assigns rank numbers (with tie handling). Returns RankedShow[] objects with rank, show metadata, totalDurationMs, and formattedDuration (composing formatDuration). Pure function building on the existing functional core utilities."}

nodes.title: showDurationRank tests passing (22/22) - green committed
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","commit":"d5fed26","confidence":95,"prompt":"TDD Green Phase committed (d5fed26): All 22 computeShowDurationRank tests passing (expanded from 2 during implementation to cover: empty shows, single show, multiple shows with varying durations, tie handling, shows with zero-duration tracks, and proper formatting of duration strings). This completes the show ranking functionality needed for the duration-based visualizations."}
